ygData.subject: Re : [neat] Benchmarks for Artificial Embryogeny Systems
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, I m not sure if it is the answer to your question... A classical benchmark is pattern formation, where the pattern is a 2d picture. - J. F. Miller,

Hi,
  I'm not sure if it is the answer to your question... A classical benc=
hmark is pattern formation, where the pattern is a 2d picture.

- J. F. Mil=
ler, Evolving a self-repairing, self-regulating, French flag organism, Gene=
tic and Evolutionary Computation (GECCO 2004), 129-139, Seattle, June, 2004=

- Using Embryonic Stages to increase the evolvability of development, in p=
roceedings of WORLDS Workshop on Regeneration and Learning in Developmental=
 Systems, hosted by GECCO 2004
- Arturo Chavoya Pena, Yves Duthen. An Artif=
icial Development Model for Cell Pattern Generation. Dans : Australian Conf=
erence on Artificial Life (ACAL 2007), Gold Coast, Australia, 04-DEC-07-06-=
DEC-07, Springer, (support =C3=A9lectronique), d=C3=A9cembre 2007. 
- Robus=
t Multi-Cellular Developmental Design. GECCO 2007, London, England, July 7-=
11th 2007. 

I'm among the authors of the latter, and it uses NEAT by the w=
ay... A pattern, called "half-disc" in that paper, is kinda hard to regress=
. 

--- En date de=C2=A0: Lun 4.8.08, Derek James <djames@...> a =C3=
=A9crit=C2=A0:

> De: Derek James <djames@...>
> Objet: [neat] Benchm=
arks for Artificial Embryogeny Systems
> =C3=80: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Dat=
e: Lundi 4 Ao=C3=BBt 2008, 6h12
> Seeing Peter Krcah's stuff (http://ero.ma=
tfyz.cz/) at
> GECCO this year
> got me re-interested in artificial embryog=
eny. I went back
> and reread
> Ken's paper "A Taxonomy for Artificial
> Em=
bryogeny"
> (http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=3D121), which is
> =
a very nice
> paper. I was specifically wondering about the suggestions
> a=
t the end
> of the paper, regarding benchmarks for AE systems, such as:
> 
=
> Evolution of:
> 
> --Pure symmetry (e.g. bilateral symmetry)
> --Specific=
 shapes (e.g. rings, stars, and trees)
> --Specific connectivity patterns (=
e.g. for neural networks)
> --Simple controllers (e.g. for double pole bala=
ncing)
> 
> Ken goes on to say:
> 
> "Such benchmark comparisons will event=
ually make it
> possible to
> predict the performance
> of AE systems based=
 on their location in the taxonomy. For
> example, one
> benchmark might be=
 to evolve a five-pointed star. This
> benchmark can
> be attempted
> with =
a system in which all the dimensions of development
> are fixed
> except th=
e cell
> fate dimension. That dimension can vary from using only
> prepatte=
rning
> to using every
> conceivable form of fate determination, from stoch=
astic
> self-organization to signaling,
> migration, and proliferation. The=
 results can be measured
> using
> several criteria: How
> fast does the ob=
jective shape evolve? How often and how
> many genes are reused by
> the so=
lution genome? Is symmetry used, or is each point in
> the star
> specified=
 by a separate
> section of genetic code=E2=80=94that is, is there emergent=

> modularity? For
> every possible
> setting on the varying dimension (e.g=
., cell fate
> determination), data
> will be available
> for comparison."
=
> 
> This sounds like a great idea. I'm wondering,
> though...what kind of
=
> response has this generated? Have there been any follow up
> papers on
> =
AE systems that have tried to apply such benchmarks in a
> systematic
> way=
?
> 
> Have these types of benchmarks been systematically applied
> to the =
2D
> representations evolved using HyperNEAT?
> 
> I also noticed rereading=
 Sims 1994 paper that he displays
> hand-coded
> examples of recognizable m=
orphologies such as a primate
> hand, a
> humanoid form, and a tree structu=
re. But I'm wondering
> if and/or how
> easy such structures arise using hi=
s encoding when starting
> from a
> simple core structure and either using =
artificial selection
> or a
> fitness function tailored to evoke similar st=
ructures.
> 
> --Derek
